pages.content:
CLIENT ASSISTANCE PROCESS

How RMs request, deliver, and document Client Assistance ‚Äî emails, scripts, and follow-through.

Purpose

  • In an ongoing effort to show our clients how much we care and value them, we have created the Client Assistance Process. Our goal is to give RMs the opportunity to reach out to upper management & see if there is anything special or extra we are able to do for the client.
  • While the process does not guarantee that we will always be able to help or do something extra for the client, we are still hoping that this will allow RMs to be able to advocate more for their clients.
1

STEP 1: PROCESS

Send an email to the address that aligns with your portfolio (see Step 2) with the following:

  • Email Subject: Client Assistance
  • Client's Name
  • Description of the situation
  • Client Account (link)
  • Proposal/Suggestion of what you‚Äôd like to do for the client

Upper management will review and determine if we‚Äôre able to help. You‚Äôll receive an email response with how to proceed.

2

STEP 2: EMAIL ADDRESSES

Email the Client Assistance inbox that matches your portfolio. Include all required details so the review is quick and clear.

  • CCL: Clientassistance@communitycreditline.com
  • PCL: Clientassistance@primecreditline.com
  • TFG: Clientassistance@titanfundinggroup.com
3

STEP 3: RESOLUTION

Once you hear back from the Client Assistance team with the decision:

  • Call the client and confirm any required details (check the reply email for what‚Äôs needed).
  • If no answer, set a follow-up and continue calling once a day for 2 more days (total of 3 attempts).
  • Send the appropriate email template for the situation.

Note: The balance will still be waived even if the client doesn‚Äôt respond. If a gift card is being sent, the client must call or email to confirm their email/home address before it can be sent.

SCRIPTS ‚Äî VOICEMAILS

First Call

Hey [client name], I've been thinking about our last conversation and wanted to follow up. I talked with my Senior Relationship Manager and have some good news for you! When you get a chance, give me a call back so I can fill you in! This is [your name] with [portfolio], and you can reach me at [phone number]. Thank you so much, and have a great day!

Send Email Template under Client Assistance titled Good News

Second Call

Hey [client name], I wanted to follow up ‚Äî you've been on my mind since our last conversation. I've got some really good news to share! Give me a call when you get a chance so I can fill you in! This is [your name] with [portfolio], and you can reach me at [phone number]. Thank you so much, and have a great day!

Send Email Template under Client Assistance titled Good News

Third Call ‚Äî If Waiving Balance

Hey [client name], this is [your name], your Relationship Manager at [portfolio]. I have some really exciting news! I talked with my Senior Relationship Manager about your situation, and wanted to do something special for you by waiving your balance with us!

There's just one condition: you have to promise to do something nice for yourself. I hope this helps take a little stress off your plate. And remember, if you ever need someone to talk to, I‚Äôm always here! Hang in there ‚Äî and don't forget, you have funds available anytime you need a little extra help! My phone number is [phone number], give me a call any time!

Send Email Template under Client Assistance titled Waiving Balance

Third Call ‚Äî If Sending Gift Card

Hey [client name], I have some really exciting news! I talked with my Senior Relationship Manager about your situation, and wanted to do something special for you and send you a gift card. Before I do that I just need you to call me to confirm a few things!

Once we have that, I'd love to get it sent over to you ‚Äî give me a call at [phone number] or email me at [email address]. Thank you so much and have a great day!

Send Email Template under Client Assistance titled Gift Card

Third Call ‚Äî Gift Card + Waiving Balance

Hey [client name], this is [your name], your Relationship Manager at [portfolio]. I have some really exciting news! I spoke with my Senior Relationship Manager about your situation, and we wanted to do something special for you ‚Äî we‚Äôve waived your remaining balance and I‚Äôd like to send you a gift card.

To get that gift card sent out, I just need to confirm a couple quick things with you. Give me a call back at [phone number].

I hope this takes a little stress off your plate and that you're able to do something nice for yourself, and remember ‚Äî if you ever need someone to talk to, I‚Äôm always here. Hang in there, and don‚Äôt forget you‚Äôve got funds available anytime you need a little extra help.

Send Email Template under Client Assistance titled Gift Card + Waiving Balance

CLIENT ANSWERS

Hey [client name], I've been thinking about our last conversation and wanted to follow up. I talked with my Senior Relationship Manager about your situation, and we decided to do something extra special for you ‚Äî we're going to [INSERT SOLUTION].

There's just one condition: You have to do something nice for yourself, so what are you gonna do?

Please Note: If we waived their balance, let them know they have funds available at any time if they could use that (unless something in the comment box suggests otherwise).

Send the corresponding email that fits the solution provided under the Client Assistance folder.

pages.title: ESCALATED CALLS & REFUNDS
pages.content:
HOW TO HANDLE ESCALATED CALLS

Step-by-step guide, actions, and advanced process ‚Äî exactly as written.

1

STEP 1

No emotion can be expressed via email text, and oftentimes they can get the wrong message when it is sent to them in email.

ACTION: Always call, NO EMAILS! If you are unable to get ahold of the client continue to call until you do, if you are leaving a voicemail make sure you give them reassurance and let them know that you're sorry this has happened and that you'll come up with a solution that will help them.

2

STEP 2

Emotion and logic do NOT go together at ALL. Escalated calls are ALWAYS emotion driven. Always assume they are emotionally driven and combat emotion with emotion, logic with logic. Preemptively bring their emotions down by using key starter phrases below:

ACTION: Diffuse the bomb BEFORE it goes off. By using these phrases, you will have disarmed 99% of their emotion and they will be much more open to recommendations you have.

STARTER PHRASES
  • "I'm so sorry this has happened."
  • "That sounds like a ton on your plate."
  • "I promise that by the end of this conversation you will be able to say I took good care of you."
  • "I'm going to get you taken care of, this is the last thing you should have to deal with."
AFTER THEY VENT

Hear them out and let them vent. When they are done venting use these key phrases:

  • "I am so sorry this has happened."
  • "You're probably stressed out of your mind."
  • "I know I can come up with a solution that will help offset some of the stress."
  • "You're handling this so much better than I would be."

Rule of Thumb: When clients call frustrated, upset, or angry, all they want is for someone to say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù Even if you didn‚Äôt do anything wrong, that simple phrase clears most hurdles. Follow it up with ‚ÄúI promise by the end of this call‚Ä¶‚Äù

3

STEP 3

What are they really saying? Remember, anger is a secondary emotion. Most often there‚Äôs an underlying emotion they aren‚Äôt willing to show. Your job is to break that barrier and get to what‚Äôs really going on.

ACTION: Peel back what they‚Äôre saying and get to the core emotion.

If they‚Äôre saying they‚Äôre stressed, frustrated, angry, or upset, they‚Äôre likely sad and telling themselves:

  • They constantly screw things up.
  • They are bad people.
  • They can‚Äôt manage their lives.

Your job is to give them hope and remind them that it‚Äôs going to be okay ‚Äî and that they‚Äôre not crazy for feeling how they do.

4

STEP 4

Proceed to give them the options approved by management.

ACTION: Don‚Äôt worry about holding a hard boundary. If the options aren‚Äôt satisfactory, don‚Äôt leave it there. Never end the call on a bad note ‚Äî tell the client you‚Äôll see what else can be done and check with your TL.

WHEN TO START

Initiate the ACS process for the following client concerns:

  • Unexpected payment amount
  • Unexpected payment date
  • Payment pulled from the wrong account
  • Misunderstanding payments/payment schedule
  • Mistake on our end
  • Escalated over a payment

IMPORTANT NOTE: Anytime you issue a refund, add an extra $15 to the total. This small gesture shows our clients we go above and beyond when something goes wrong‚Äîand that we truly care. You are also required to tell the client to ‚Äúdo something nice for yourself‚Äù when sending the refund.

ADVANCED CUSTOMER SERVICE PROCESS

1

Check if the client had a refund (overdraft, full payment, or a combination).

IF YES: Have they had two refunds?

If yes, see TL.

If no, proceed to step 3.

IF NO:

Proceed to step 3.

2

Examine the comment box for refund errors.

IMPORTANT NOTE: If a REFUND ERROR comment exists, WAIT FOR THE PAYMENT TO SETTLE ON ANY FUTURE REFUND for a full payment or combination of full payment/overdraft fee. This applies to each portfolio individually.

If a refund error occurred & we're refunding a full payment or combo, check if the payment has settled

  • If NOT SETTLED: Wait for payment to clear before refunding.
  • If SETTLED: Proceed.
3

Ask if the payment will clear.

IF YES

For Full Payment Only: Read the Refund authorization script, specifying the date of final payment. (Figure this out manually, LMS will not generate).

  • Copy template for underwriter follow-up.
  • Refund full payment [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.] and send the Future Payments email on RM's behalf.

Full Payment + Overdraft: Read the Refund authorization script for both.

  • Copy template for underwriter follow-up.
  • Refund full payment [amount] and overdraft fee [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.] and send the Future Payments email on RM's behalf.
IF NO
  • Offer to cover an overdraft fee if applicable.
  • Read the Refund authorization script for overdraft.
  • Copy template for underwriter follow-up.
  • Refund overdraft fee [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.] and send the Future Payments email on RM's behalf.

REFUND RULES

  • Only TWO refunds per loan can be approved by an RM, anything over TWO see a TL. This includes overdrafts, full payments, or a combo of full payment/overdraft. Do not inform clients of a refund limit per loan.
  • No partial refunds allowed (only full payment, overdraft, or combination of the two).
  • If it's the client's first due date with a promo, the promo will no longer be valid. Please note: if the payment returns, you will re-schedule just the promo amount.
  • Refunds cannot be done over email.
  • We cannot refund onto a card.
  • Extensions can be added on top of a refund if necessary; check Change Due Dates for available extensions.

If a client revokes our authorization, stops payments, or falls in the regulatory category:

  • Read the Refund authorization script for refunding a full payment/overdraft/combo.
  • Copy and paste template below to leave a follow-up for your underwriter.
  • Refund full payment [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.]. Mark account Regulatory/Revoke/Stop Payment/DC/BK.
  • Refund overdraft fee [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.]. Mark account Regulatory/Revoke/Stop Payment/DC/BK.
  • Refund full payment [amount] and overdraft fee [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.]. Mark account Regulatory/Revoke/Stop Payment/DC/BK.

EXTENSIONS & PAYMENT PLANS

Courtesy & Emergency Extensions, Good Faith Payments, Grace Periods, and Referral Skips.

CHEATSHEET

Option When to Use Limit Key Rule / Notes
Courtesy Extension First extension on an active loan 1 per loan Use before Emergency; cancels promo if on first due date
Emergency Extension After a Courtesy Extension 1 per loan Cannot follow a Courtesy applied to prior payment
Good Faith Payment (GFP) After both extensions or Courtesy without payment in between 2 per loan $25 fee (or $15 if ‚â§ $30); not applied to principal
Grace Period Client needs up to 3 business days Unlimited Moves payment ‚â§ 3 days; TEL/WEB authorization
Referral Source Extension When a client refers someone 1 per referral One-time skip; promo remains valid on first payment
Payment Plan After all extensions are exhausted or for longer-term hardship N/A (typically 6‚Äì8 payments) No extensions on PP; ‚àí$100 credit limit; TEL auth; no early pmts (except PIF)
üí°

Important Notes

  • Notate why an extension was given (context matters).
  • You cannot apply an extension at loan creation; clients must call before their due date.
  • Cutoff: Adjustments for payments due the next business day must be submitted by 3:40 PM.
  • Card payments can be adjusted if not processed ‚Äî the 3:40 PM rule doesn‚Äôt apply to card payments.
  • If the client‚Äôs first due date has a promo, the discount no longer applies. Update that payment to the regular finance charge.

AVAILABLE EXTENSIONS

  • Courtesy Extension: 1 per loan ‚Äî extends one full due date.
  • Emergency Extension: 1 per loan ‚Äî extends one full due date.
  • Good Faith Payment (GFP): up to 2 per loan ‚Äî $25 fee extends the original payment one due date.
  • Grace Periods: Unlimited ‚Äî moves original payment out 3 business days (or less).

If all extensions are used: See the Payment Plan tab.

COURTESY EXTENSION

First option for an active loan with no prior extensions used.

SET UP EXTENSION
  1. Go to Payments ‚Üí Change Due Dates.
  2. Enter the adjusted date under New Due Date.
  3. Select Courtesy Extension as the reason.
  4. Ask them to do something nice for themselves.
  5. Read the authorization script verbatim.
  6. Send the Courtesy/Emergency/GFP/PP email.
  7. Ensure future payments are labeled TEL.

To confirm, we will be moving your original payment due on [original due date] in the amount of [amount] to [new due date] in the amount of [amount]. This transaction will come out of your account ending in [last 4 digits of account or card number]. Your new pay in full date will now be [end date]. Is that correct? Do we have your permission to proceed?

CREATING PAYMENT PLAN

Payment plans are a LAST RESORT option, offered only after exhausting all available extensions.

PROMOTION

Promotions no longer apply on the client's first due date; have your TL adjust BEFORE creating a payment plan.

IN GRACE PERIOD

If you're setting up or adjusting a payment plan during a grace period, consult your TL for guidance.

CUT OFF TIME

If a client calls at 3:40 to adjust a payment due the next business day, inform them that we missed the cutoff time, and the payment is already in process.

CARD PAYMENTS

Card payments can be adjusted as long as they haven‚Äôt been processed; the 3:40 PM rule doesn‚Äôt apply to card payments.

SETTING UP PP

Payment plans CANNOT be set up while a payment is still processing. Call back once it settles and leave the RM a follow-up for 1 week out.

PAYMENT PLAN PROCESS

OFFERING

Start with available extensions unless hardship is long-term. Use judgment.

NEGOTIATE

Begin with 6 payments; if needed move to 7, then 8. Give them time to respond before offering the next option.

IMPORTANT NOTES
  • Once a payment plan is in place, no extensions are allowed ‚Äî this includes second GFPs.
  • Payment plan will reduce credit limit by $100.
  • No early payments on plans (except Pay in Full).
ACCOUNT CONFIRMATION

Confirm pay frequency and bank details (be specific).

ADDING A PAYMENT PLAN
  • Click Add Payment Plan and select the agreed number of payments.
  • Change authorization type to TEL.
  • Click Save Payment Plan.
  • Ask them to do something nice for themselves.
  • Read the Payment Plan authorization script.
  • Send the Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, & PP email.
  • Check Change Payments page to ensure all future payments are labeled: TEL
  • Decrease the credit limit $100 from the BORROWED amount.

PAYMENT PLAN FAQs

  • If the client insists on reducing payments, consult your TL. Extensions (except grace periods) on a payment plan require TL approval.
Extensions on a Payment Plan

To extend a payment plan, get TL approval and follow these steps:

  1. Click Edit Payment Plan.
  2. Under Next Payment Date, type in the date you are trying to move the payment to.
  3. For good faith payments, manually create the $25 in Change Payments:
    • Transaction Type: Fee
    • Authorization Type: TEL
    • Payment Method: Make sure it‚Äôs defaulted to correct account
    • Amount: $25
    • Scheduled: The original date the payment was due
  4. Ask them to do something nice for themselves.
  5. Read the Good Faith Payment authorization script.
  6. Send Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, & PP email.
Making an Early Payment on a Payment Plan

We no longer accept early payments on payment plans.

Restarting Payment Plan Payments When Assigned to OPS

If client was already on a payment plan before:

  1. Click Edit Payment Plan.
  2. Select Recreate Payment.
  3. Read the Past Due authorization script.
  4. Send the Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, & PP email.
  5. Make sure the credit limit was decreased $100 from the BORROWED amount.
  6. Leave your underwriter a follow-up to reassign to the RM.

If client was not on a payment plan before:

  1. Click Add Payment Plan and select the number of payments the client agreed to.
  2. Change the authorization type to TEL.
  3. Click Save Payment Plan.
  4. Read the Payment Plan authorization script.
  5. Send the Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, & PP email.
  6. Decrease the credit limit $100 from the BORROWED amount.
  7. Leave your underwriter a follow-up to reassign to the RM.
Scheduling a Payment on a Payment Plan
  1. Click Edit Payment Plan.
  2. Select Recreate Payment.
  3. Check your work.
Important Note: If a scheduled past due payment needs an extension, update the date in Edit Payment Plan, it will adjust the pending payment accordingly.
Scheduling a Grace Period on a Payment Plan
  1. Click Edit Payment Plan.
  2. Select the date you are trying to move it to.
  3. Check your work.
  4. Read the Extensions/Grace Period authorization script.

Important Notes:

  • These steps also apply when setting up a payment plan initially. Set the plan for the original due date, then go to View to add the grace period.
  • If you are creating or modifying a payment plan in a grace period see your TL for instructions
Updating Bank Account on a Payment Plan
  1. Click Edit Customer.
  2. Under Payment Method, select New Bank Account from the drop-down menu (unless the account is already on file).
  3. Verify that the client's name is on the account if we've never taken payments from the account before.
  4. Save.
  5. Read the Payment Method Change authorization script.
  6. Send Future Payments email.
Updating Card Information
  1. Click Edit Customer.
  2. Under Payment Method, select New Credit Card from the drop-down menu (unless the card is already on file).
  3. Save.
  4. Click Edit Payment Plan.
  5. Under Payment Method, select the card in the drop-down menu the client wishes to use.
Updating Pay Frequency on a Payment Plan
  1. Select Edit Payment Plan and remove the payment plan.
  2. Click Edit Customer.
  3. Update pay frequency and press Save.
  4. Set the payment plan back up by clicking on Add Payment Plan.
  5. Read the Pay Frequency Change authorization script.
  6. Send Future Payments email.
Important Note: If altering the pay frequency changes the loan balance or leads to a past-due status, record the client's remaining payments and amounts before removing the payment plan. Leave a follow-up for your TL to adjust the account.

pages.title: PAUSE/STOP PAYMENT/REVOKE
pages.content:
PAUSE PAYMENT & REVOKE/STOP PAYMENT

Process, rules, setup steps, and scripts. (Wording preserved exactly as provided.)

PAUSE PROCESS

IMPORTANT NOTE: The Pause Payment process requires TL approval before initiating.

WHEN TO START THE PAUSE PROCESS ‚ñæ

If a client revokes our authorization or requests to stop payments due to financial hardship without alleging any illegality, seek TL approval to pause payments. This process is used when a client expresses the need to halt payments, and a regular extension isn't sufficient. The client may use phrases like:

  • ‚ÄúCan I stop payments?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI need to hold my payments.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúCan I pause my payments?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI cannot have you automatically withdraw payments.‚Äù

PAUSE PAYMENT RULES

Rules ‚ñæ
  • The client‚Äôs credit limit will NOT decrease.
  • Offering available extensions or payment plan options initially is not required.
  • This does not take away from original extensions still available on the loan.
For Email Requests ‚ñæ
  • If a client emails to revoke authorization or stop payments, consult your TL.
  • After devising a plan with TL approval, call the client to start the Pause Payment process.
  • If the client doesn't answer, initiate the Revoke Authorization/Stop Payment process.
Alternate Scenario ‚ñæ
  • If offering to pause payments and the client still revokes authorization or requests to stop payments, consult your TL.
  • With TL approval, proceed to the Revoke Authorization/Stop Payment process.

SETTING PAUSE ON ACTIVE OR PAST DUE ACCOUNT

Steps ‚ñæ
  1. Go to Payments.
  2. Click on Change Due Dates.
  3. Enter the agreed-upon due date under New Due Date.
  4. Select Pause as the reason for changing the date.
  5. Ask the client to do something nice for themselves.
  6. Read the Extension authorization script.
  7. Send the Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, & PP email.
  8. Notate the exception made.
  9. Schedule a follow-up for the client's RM 3 business days before the due date as a reminder.

SETTING UP PAUSE ON PAYMENT PLAN OR PAYMENT PLAN PAST DUE

Steps ‚ñæ
  1. Go to Edit Payment Plan.
  2. Enter the agreed-upon due date under Next Payment Date.
  3. Ask the client to do something nice for themselves.
  4. Read the Extension authorization script.
  5. Send the Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, & PP email.
  6. Notate the exception made.
  7. Schedule a follow-up for the client's RM 3 business days before the due date as a reminder.

REVOKE AUTHORIZATION/STOP PAYMENT PROCESS

IMPORTANT NOTE: You CANNOT initiate the Revoke Authorization/Stop Payment process without your TL's approval.

Overview ‚ñæ

If a client revokes our authorization or requests to stop payment due to financial hardship without alleging illegality and declines the Pause Payment process, consult your TL about initiating the Revoke Authorization/Stop Payment process. Once approved, proceed.

IF DONE OVER EMAIL ‚ñæ

VOICEMAIL: Hey (client name), I understand from your email that you're facing challenges. I've paused your payments to provide some relief. If you'd like to discuss further options or when things settle down, feel free to call me at [phone number].

CLIENT ANSWERS: Hey (client name), I received your email and understand it's a tough time. I can pause your payments, shifting your due date from [original due date] to [new due date]. Would that be helpful?

If the client declines or doesn't respond:

  • Send the Revoke Authorization/Stop Payment email via Gmail.
  • Attach files.
  • Mark the account either Revoke or Stop Payment.
  • Create a follow-up for a month from today stating send PD 3 email, leave the underwriter a follow-up to send the client to OPS, if no contact after a month.
IF DONE OVER THE PHONE ‚ñæ

Consult your TL for options. If the client persists in revoking authorization or stopping payments after discussing alternatives do the following:

  • Attach relevant files.
  • Mark the account either Revoke or Stop Payment.
  • Create a follow-up for a month from today stating send PD 3 email, leave the underwriter a follow-up to send the client to OPS, if no contact after a month.

IMPORTANT NOTES

  • If a client revokes authorization, stops payments, or falls into the regulatory category with an outstanding refund (e.g., overdraft fee or full payment), inform your underwriter via follow-up to label the account as Revoke/Stop Payment or Regulatory. Do not make this change independently to ensure the refund process proceeds correctly.

pages.content:
Office Environment

Alternative Work Location

Designated employees, determined in each department on an individual basis, will be allowed one remote workday per pay period (i.e., two per month, except for two months that will have three). These days must be scheduled in advance so everyone knows who will be working remotely and when, and they can be worked back-to-back within the same month if desired. Because some individuals cannot be absent from the office at the same time, overlapping remote workdays must be approved in advance.

Alternative Work Location Expectations

  • Stable primary internet connection required (must verify this beforehand)
  • Secondary network connection strongly advised (e.g., 5G/LTE with hotspot capability on mobile device)
  • Laptop with preconfigured VPN access to office network
  • Clean and clear workspace that includes a power outlet (or one nearby)
  • Must work the full 8-hour shift: 7:30 AM - 4:00 PM MST (Please note: If you're working out of the country or from a location whose timezone is not MST, you still have to work your shift from 7:30 AM - 4:00 PM MST. That means that you've got to figure out what that time block would be from your current location and be working during those hours, even if it's 3:00 AM where you are.)
  • Travel must be avoided during business hours
  • Must stay within a 15-minute radius of your workstation if you go on lunch or break
  • If working from home, you need to be able and available to drive in to the office if an emergency arises
  • The Acceptable Use Policy, Information Security Policy, all standard data security practices, and all company policies need to be observed as though you were working in the office

A final note: Working remotely is a privilege that is granted on an individual basis. Please be advised that it is also subject to individual withdrawal at any time.

Dress Code: Business Casual

We expect each employee to dress appropriately for work by adhering to the following rules:

  • No low-cut tops that show your bra.
  • No bottoms that show your bum.
  • No clothing that displays profane language.
  • Spandex leggings, biker shorts, and yoga pants must not be see-through
  • No sweats, sweat shorts, terry cloth shorts, track pants, loungewear, or pajamas.
  • See-through clothing is prohibited.

Our goal is to provide a workplace environment that is comfortable and inclusive for all employees. Please wear something that helps you feel confident and ready to take on the day in the most positive way possible.

Hobby

Building real connections with our clients is at the heart of what we do. It's not just about what we sayit's about how it translates into their experience with us. If we don't take a genuine interest in our clients during the application process, we're no different from any other lender. Our goal is to show them that it's not just about the loanit's about helping them see their value and know that THEY MATTER. That's why obtaining a hobby is a required part of our process.

If you assist a client (whether they belong to you or not) and do not obtain a hobby (new or returning client), you will not receive credit for the loan. If the client does not belong to you, one of your own loans from that day/pay period will be deducted instead. You must actively ask the client about their hobbyit's not enough to simply record a detail they mentioned without directly asking for it.

BAD EXAMPLE (that wont count): Client is talking about the weather with you and mentions they like the rain, you record that as their hobby.

GOOD EXAMPLE: "I like to get to know my clients a little better, what do you like to do for fun?" Or "What is a hobby you enjoy doing?"

The client will still belong to you, but for that pay period, they will be reassigned to the QA department. No commission will be paid on that loan.

Important Notes:

  • If it is found that a hobby was entered without actually asking the client, a written warning will be issued.
  • In the event the client doesn't share their hobby after you've asked, please put this in the comment box (every time you ask) not the hobby box. Since it's not actually their hobby, we want to keep asking until we get a real one! You are required to continue asking on future calls until we get an actual hobby.

Keeping The Office Clean

Many improvements have been made to our office in order to create an atmosphere that is clean, inviting, and professional. We expect every employee to be responsible and clean up after themselves. Each time you leave items out or fail to pick up after yourself, especially in the break area and kitchen, 10% of your commission will be deducted from your paycheck for that pay period for each occurrence.

Payroll Logic

Online Loan

  • If the Assigned to relationship manager was clocked in at the time of approval OR had already worked 8+ hours that day, the loan is credited to them.
  • If the Assigned to relationship manager wasn't there that day, we check their buddy. If the buddy was clocked in at the time of approval OR had already worked 8+ hours that day, the loan is credited to them.
  • If neither of the above scenarios apply, no one is credited for the loan.

Phone Loan

  • If the Assigned to relationship manager was clocked in at the time of approval OR had already worked 8+ hours that day, the loan is credited to them.
  • If the Assigned to relationship manager wasn't there that day, we check their buddy. If the buddy was clocked in at the time of approval OR had already worked 8+ hours that day, the loan is credited to them.
  • If neither of the above scenarios is applicable, we check who the loan was created by. If that person was clocked in at the time of approval OR had already worked 8+ hours that day, the loan is credited to them.
  • If none of the above scenarios apply, no one is credited for the loan.

Important note for Assigned to relationship managers: You must work a full 8 hours to be compensated for the loan. Working almost 8 hours, even if you're just 5 minutes shy, isn't going to cut it. In order to be compensated for the loan, you must complete an entire day's work.

Policies & Security

Acceptable Use of Computers, IT Equipment and Networks

This Acceptable Use Policy covers the use of all (iLS LLC's) IT equipment excluding security related policies found in the Information Security Policy.

Individuals must not:

  • Use the internet for personal purposes, which would include, but are not limited to, social media platforms, chats, personal email, etc.
  • Download any software from the internet without prior approval of Management
  • Install or use any software unrelated to the job (even if it is built into Operating system or Web Browser), including all games
  • Use the internet or email for the purposes of harassment or abuse
  • Access, download, send or receive any data (including images), which (iLS LLC) considers offensive in any way, including sexually explicit, discriminatory, defamatory or libelous material
  • Discuss religion or politics in writing on ANY iLS platform (e.g., wiki, chat, email, gratitude chain, etc.). We also ask that you refrain from using profanity
  • Use the internet or email to make personal gains or conduct a personal business.
  • Download copyrighted material such as music media (MP3) files, film and video files (not an exhaustive list) without appropriate approval
  • In any way infringe any copyright, database rights, trademarks or other intellectual property.
  • Store personal files such as music, video, photographs or games on (iLS LLC) IT equipment
  • Remove or disable anti-virus software or Web Proxy Settings
  • Connect any devices via Bluetooth or USB without IT approval

It is your responsibility to report suspected breaches of policies without delay to your line management or the IT department. All breaches of Acceptable Use policy will be investigated. Where investigations reveal misconduct, disciplinary action may follow.

Corrective Action

If an employee fails to adhere to any company policy or audit-related items that are crucial for compliance, corrective action will be taken.

  • First occurrence: First notice
  • Second occurrence: Verbal warning
  • Third occurrence: Written warning
  • Fourth occurrence: Termination

All warnings will roll off an employee's record 6 months from the date the first notice was given, and warnings will not reset at the beginning of each year. (For example: An employee is given a first notice regarding expectation, policy, or audit/compliance item on March 1. The employee has a second occurrence and receives a verbal warning on April 1, and then a third occurrence, for which they receive a written warning, on May 1. On September 1, six months from the first notice date, all warnings would be removed from the employee's record.)

Disciplinary Topics

  • Participating in and/or creating drama
  • Gossiping
  • Talking badly about clients/coworkers
  • Spreading rumors
  • Dishonesty
  • Lying
  • Stealing from the company
  • Keeping important details from management
  • Coming in early or staying late to get overtime and not actually working
  • Other
  • Sleeping on the clock
  • Using, possessing, buying, selling, manufacturing or dispensing an illegal drug while working
  • Possessing or consuming alcohol on the job
  • Failing to complete assignments or adhere to company policies

Please note: This does not represent a complete or comprehensive list of behaviors that will initiate disciplinary action at iLS, but the above-mentioned examples are meant to give you an idea of conduct that will not be tolerated here.

Information Security Policy

Sensitive Material

  • Employees cannot take any work-related material containing customer information out of the office.
  • Photos are not to be taken inside the office where there is potentially sensitive information.

Electronic Devices (PCs, Laptops, Tablets, Phones)

  • All work-related electronic devices must be password protected and remain in a locked state when not actively being used.
  • All employees possessing mobile devices with sensitive information (e.g., customer information) or access to iLS Google services must first obtain permission from IT for that access, and then abide by the following rules:
    • Mobile devices must be protected with a login or lock screen that requires a password, fingerprint, pattern, or pin for access.
    • Mobile devices and/or the directory on the device that contains sensitive information should be encrypted.

Passwords

  • Passwords must be at least 8 characters and have at least 1 capital letter and 1 number or symbol.
  • Passwords cannot contain personal information (e.g., phone number, SSN, address, name).
  • Passwords may not be shared with anyone for any reason at any time unless explicit permission is granted from management.

Open Door Policy

Open communication is critical to understanding and meeting the needs of our employees and customers. Through our open door policy, employees are encouraged to share their suggestions, ideas, and concerns. Whether you need help with a problem, guidance, or simply want an answer to a question, we are here for you! Holding in something that is bothering youwhether it be an issue with pay, time off, or something elseis not good. If you let it stew, it will cause extra stress and affect your ability to do loans. We want to hear what's on your mind. Please don't ever feel like you can't talk to us; our door is always open to you.

pages.title: Time & Attendence
pages.content:
Time & Attendance

Being On Time

Arriving on time and prepared to work sets the tone for your day and is crucial for achieving success. When you're tardy, you break commitments you've made to the company and to yourself, and that negatively affects your self-confidence.

Please note: We will no longer allow employees to arrive 59 minutes late without it deducting from their PTO/ETO.

What Counts as a Tardy?

If you are not using PTO/ETO, the following will count as a tardy:

  • Any clock-in time after 7:30 AM.
  • Taking more than the allotted 30-minute lunch.
  • Exceeding your 15-minute breaks.

Things to Keep in Mind:

  • A deduction from your PTO/ETO balance will occur any time you are 15 minutes late (i.e., you clock in at 7:45 AM, take a 45-minute lunch, or take a 30-minute break). ETO time does not remove the tardy since there are not paid hours to offset that time. If you do not have any PTO/ETO available, corrective action will be taken. No exceptions.
  • If a relationship manager is late more than 2 times in a pay period, 10% of their commission will be deducted from their paycheck for each subsequent tardy. Example: A relationship manager is late 4 times in a pay period = 20% of their commission will be deducted from their paycheck.
  • Important: Warnings for excessive tardies will be given at management's discretion.

Breaks

One 15-minute break is provided per 4-hour shift. (Two 15-minute breaks are afforded for 8-hour shifts.) Please don't forget to take your breaks. This time is for using the restroom and taking care of any other personal needs you may have. Do not exceed 15 minutes per break.

A half-hour unpaid lunch is provided per 8-hour shift. Assigned lunch breaks are dependent on shift time.

These breaks are for you and taking them is so important. You will do more loans as a result of properly taking your breaks. Go for a walk, get a drink, give your mind a break, and then come back and hit it hard! You will see more results with less effort if you choose to take advantage of your breaks.

Important note: Because we are growing, we now need to assign break times to ensure that we always have enough relationship managers on the floor to take care of our clients. Breaks are great for taking a breather, and they also give you the chance to reach out and talk with the new hires. Please take advantage of this opportunity!

Punctuality and Communication

If you simply fail to show up for work and we don't receive any communication regarding your absence, corrective action may be taken.

Time Off Policy

New Hires

Paid time off (PTO) will be on an accrual basis and will commence from their start date until they reach one year of service with the company. PTO will accrue at a rate of 4.615 hours per pay period, with a cap of 120 hours which equates to 15 days. Accrual will continue until their one-year anniversary month and will not reset to zero on January 1st. Upon reaching their one-year anniversary month, all accrued PTO up to the designated cap will be frontloaded, and thereafter, on each subsequent anniversary date. PTO balances will never exceed the cap set in place by iLS policies.

If all PTO has been used/there is no PTO available, new hires will be provided 5 days of unpaid ETO. ETO resets on the pay period when your anniversary date falls.

Existing Employees (Transition to New Policy for First Year Only)

For employees hired prior to 4/18/24, rather than receiving all accrued days frontloaded on 1/1/25, PTO will be prorated based on their hire month. On the pay period when their anniversary date falls, employees will then be fully transitioned to the new Time Off Policy and will receive all their PTO days, up to their cap, added to their balance.

For example, if your hire date is in September, on January 1, 2025, your prorated PTO will be 10 days. In September 2025, on the pay period when your anniversary date falls, you will receive all your PTO frontloaded and every September thereafter, you will have all your days frontloaded. PTO balances will never exceed the cap set in place by iLS policies.

If all PTO has been used/there is no PTO available each employee will be provided 5 days of unpaid ETO. ETO resets January 1, 2025, but will also reset again on the pay period when their anniversary date falls, then each subsequent year, ETO will reset on their anniversary date.

All Employees

Employees are not permitted to skip their lunch. If you need to leave early, that time will be deducted from your PTO/ETO balance.

Every year you are with the company, you will receive an additional day of PTO distributed on your anniversary date. This accrual will cap at 20 PTO days/year.

Special Circumstances

An employee may choose to use PTO for special circumstances, or opt to not get paid. If an employee is summoned for jury duty, iLS may request that a note from the court be provided. The amount of time off allotted for bereavement and court appearances is up to the discretion of management.

If you do not have any PTO/ETO left and you're getting married, we will allow you to take 5 working days of unpaid time off.

Corrective Action

If you do not have any time off available and you leave early or you're 15 minutes late in the morning, getting back from lunch, or from break, corrective action will be taken. The Executive team reserves the right to review exceptions on a case-by-case basis.

Additional Notes:

  • Time off requests must be submitted through the WhenIWork app.
  • If you experience issues submitting your request through WhenIWork, please send your request via email to: timeoff@ileadserve.com.
  • Time off requests must be submitted prior to the start of your shift; otherwise, warnings will be issued.
  • If you need additional time off after submitting your initial request, you must submit a secondary request through WhenIWork so we know when to expect you back.
  • No time off will be permitted during the training period (i.e., first 2 weeks). No exceptions.
  • If you are requesting 2 or more days off, please give us two days' notice. For anything under 2 days, please let managers know as soon as possible. The max amount of time that an employee can take off at one time is 2 weeks.
  • Please do not request time off more than 6 months in advance.
  • Any unused PTO will NOT be paid out on your anniversary date. We want you to use your time off so that you can recharge and take a break. Use it, don't lose it!
  • If an employee is terminated, any unused PTO will NOT be paid out.
  • Please note: consistent last-minute (same-day) time-off requests may result in a warning, at management's discretion. "Last-minute" also includes requests that come in overnight or over the weekend. The question to ask is: did you do anything in advance to help with workload? Even if it's submitted outside business hours, it still creates the same amount of work.

Maternity Leave

When a relationship manager goes on maternity leave, it is crucial that their clients continue to receive excellent service. To ensure that this happens, a relationship manager's portfolio of clients will be distributed amongst the other relationship managers in the portfolio when they go on leave. When the relationship manager returns, they will receive the same number of clients with the same distribution they had when they left. (e.g., If the RM had 40 active clients and 100 VCs when they left, they will receive 40 active clients and 100 VCs when they return.)

Please note: We do NOT guarantee that the relationship manager will have the same clients they had before they went on leave; we only ensure that the relationship manager will have the same number of clients with the same distribution.

pages.title: Work Performance
pages.content:
Work Performance

Commission Expectation

Each RM has a goal of 5 loans per day with the exception of TFG, where the expectation is 7. These expectations are an average reference point to help you know how many clients you should be able to serve. By focusing on serving your clients effectively, these numbers should be naturally attainable.

PLEASE NOTE: New hires will be granted a grace period before being held to the standard loan requirements. The length of this grace period is yet to be determined.

Loan Assignment

New loans will be assigned to the person who notated that they last called using a marketing script, unless the client specifically requests a different representative. This applies to referrals as well.

If there is no note or "last called by", the loan assignment will go to whoever took the inbound call.

If neither situation applies, it will go to the person the follow-up was left for.

In the event the call drops, please call the client back to finish the application (whether you are going to be their Relationship Manager or not). The client will still be assigned to the RM who originally called the client.

All returning clients stay with the original RM.

Loan Production Requirement Policy

This policy is designed to ensure consistent loan production from RMs while providing them with a clear understanding of expectations. These seats are valuable and we want to make sure they are filled with individuals pulling their weight.

All Relationship Managers are expected to bring in a total of 105 loans per calendar month, based on their own book, and regardless of the number of days worked during that month.

New hires will be granted a grace period before being held to the standard loan requirements. The length of this grace period is yet to be determined.

If an RM fails to meet the monthly target, they have one additional month to reach it. Failure to meet the requirement for two consecutive months results in termination.

Please note: The 105 loans per month requirement is subject to change. Upper management will notify you of any adjustments.

New Loan Production Requirement Policy

Each RM will be required to convert a minimum of 6 new loans each month. Failure to meet the goal will result in a warning following the company's current corrective action policy. Which is as follows:

  • First month under 6 new loans: First Notice
  • Under 6 new loans with prior First Notice: Verbal
  • Under 6 new loans with prior Verbal: Written
  • Under 6 new loans with prior Written: Termination

Please note: All warnings will roll of 6 months from when the Verbal warning was issued. This policy is subject to periodic review and may be adjusted based on performance trends. Upper management will notify you of any adjustments.

Focus On Connection

Our primary goal is to focus on connecting with our clients and bettering their lives. It is impossible to do this if we're not fully present in our interactions with them. Accordingly, activities that take your focus away from being present with your clients on the phones are restricted. These include the following:

  • Reading
  • Using Google for personal use (e.g., shopping)
  • Sudoku
  • Crosswords
  • Word searches
  • Playing games (unless it's a raffle game we're doing here at work)
  • Journaling
  • Coloring

The above examples do not constitute a complete or comprehensive list of behaviors relative to this policy that will initiate disciplinary action. Please focus on listening to your clients and being there for them!

IMPORTANT NOTE: You're not allowed to journal at work, but please feel free to write down intentions, affirmations, or goals.

Zone

Zone is our time to come together and focus on one mission: bringing hope back to our clients. When we all tune in without distractions, we're able to give clients our full attention, set everything else aside for a bit, and see better results.

It usually takes about 45 minutes of doing the same thingdialingto really hit your stride. That's why staying at your desk during zone is so important. Once you break focus, it's harder to get back into that rhythm where the best conversations happen. And when everyone is locked in at the same time, the energy on the floor is contagious.

Our zone times are:

  • 8:30 AM 10:00 AM: New list (63 dials minimum)
  • 1:00 PM 2:30 PM: New list (62 dials minimum, 125 total per day)

During Zone, You Can:

  • Dial.
  • Work new pending loans (including current ones with updated info).
  • Do new LWOPs or MPs (these follow-ups will generate automatically).

During Zone, You Cannot:

  • Work on anything outside the three tasks listed above.
  • Answer non-sales emails.
  • Go grab snacks from the kitchen.
  • Use the restroom (unless it's truly unavoidablebut don't make it a habit).
  • Clean your desk.
  • Do anything that pulls your focus off sales.
  • Distract other RMswhether that's chatting, planning lunch, goofing off, or emailing back and forth.

Zone is about protecting your focus and respecting everyone else's focus, too. Sticking to these expectations helps all of us succeed and if Zone is not followed, warnings may be issued at management's discretion.

pages.title: Workplace Conduct
pages.content:
Workplace Conduct

Call Etiquette

When interacting with clients on the phone, we always want to be respectful. We expect that you'll never hang up on a client or hang up on a voicemail before leaving one. If it is discovered either of these circumstances has occurred, corrective action may be taken.

At iLS, we focus on serving our clients, and our etiquette on the phone is a huge piece of that. Hanging up doesn't communicate that we care, and it's also a waste of a lead. We've worked hard to build this company and secure it, and we want you to give every lead a chance for success.

Cell Phones and Smartwatches

Due to the sensitive nature of client information that we deal with and to stay in compliance with federal regulation, cell phone and smartwatch use on the call floor is not permitted. Please remove your smartwatches and put them away. You may have your cell phone/smartwatch nearby in case of an emergency (this is what your filing cabinet is for), but do not use either device on the call floor.

For clarity: The "call floor" is considered any carpeted area outside of private offices.

Cell phones and smartwatches are often a distraction and get in the way of productive workdays. If you're seen using them on the call floor, you'll receive a warning from the floor manager. If it happens again, you'll be terminated.

Please note: If you have a medical condition that requires you to wear a smartwatch, please alert HR so that we can make an exception.

Swearing

To maintain a professional and respectful environment, swearing or the use of profane, crude, or obscene language is not permitted in any client interaction. This includes phone calls, voicemails, emails, text messages, and internal notes related to the client.

As Relationship Managers, your words carry weight, and we expect all communications - spoken and written - to reflect the care, compassion, and professionalism our clients deserve.

Talking Negatively About Clients

Our company's mission is to validate and give hope to each of our clients. Though they've been treated otherwise by our competitors, they deserve to be treated with respect and we wouldn't be here without them.

If negative comments--about our clients or each other--are discussed on the call floor, face-to-face, through iLS chat, or in a client's notes or comment box in LMS, a written warning will be issued to the individuals involved. If there's a second occurrence following the written warning, the involved parties will be terminated.

If you have had an experience with a difficult client, TAKE IT OFF THE FLOOR. Do not write about it in the notes or comment box. Get validation from your team lead or the floor manager. The notes and comment box are not appropriate places to complain. Saying something there will not resolve the issue, and whoever takes the call when the client calls in again will read those notes and make automatic assumptions about the client. Our clients are good people who are often going through extremely difficult trials. Please remember: Even if it might feel like it in the moment, it's not personal! If a client is defensive, they are likely assuming that they will be treated the way they've been treated by other lenders in the past. Try your best to give them the benefit of the doubt!

pages.title: AUDITING
pages.content:
CONNECTION, ACCOUNTABILITY & COMPLIANCE

Give hope. Help people feel like they matter‚Äîon every single call.

AUDITING & ACCOUNTABILITY

We don‚Äôt want to box you in with a checklist of ‚Äúyou must say this, this, and this‚Äù‚Äîbecause when connection becomes a script, it loses its authenticity, and the client can feel it.

What we do expect is care, connection, and validation throughout every call.

Anyone can check boxes and follow a process. What sets you apart is your willingness to take a few extra seconds to fill the dead air, to leave clients better than you found them‚Äîby offering hope, by helping them feel like they matter.

You do that by staying present. By asking about them. By listening closely and picking up on the small things they share, and actually engaging with what they say.

Because of this, we will no longer allow coloring or any other activities that pull your attention away from your calls. We want you fully connected, and distractions like these are preventing that from happening.

This is not optional. Warnings will be issued if you're not actively putting these expectations into play. This matters sooooo much.

GOAL EVERY CALL

Give hope. Help every client feel like they matter.
Whether they‚Äôre calling in for a new loan, a past-due balance, or just needing support‚Äîour clients deserve empathy, validation, and connection from the first word to the last. That starts with you.

Core Expectations (Apply to Every Call)

  • Stay present and actively listen; pick up on the details and ask questions.
  • Lead with connection. Fill in the dead air.
  • Listen to understand, not just to respond.
  • Warm tone‚Äînot monotone, rushed, frustrated, or disinterested.
  • Speak to the person, not just the account.
  • Never hang up on a client.
  • Use validating phrases to show you care.

CONNECTION NON-NEGOTIABLES

These are foundational pieces for new clients, returning clients, and anytime we‚Äôre helping alleviate stress‚Äîregardless of the reason for the call:

  • ‚úÖ Ask how they are doing
  • ‚úÖ Ask the client to do something nice for themselves
  • ‚úÖ Follow up: ‚ÄúWhat are you going to do?‚Äù
  • ‚úÖ Ask about their hobby or interest
    ‚Ü≥ Ask follow-up questions to show genuine interest

‚úÖ DO NOT RESERVE THESE PIECES FOR THE END OF THE CALL!!

These are not optional. These are the moments that change how people feel‚Äîabout the call, about themselves, and about us.

CONNECTION & VALIDATION

Here are some examples of what strong connection and validation look like in everyday conversations:

Asking Meaningful Questions
  • ‚ÄúHow is your day going so far?‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs making it so good?‚Äù / ‚ÄúWhy just fine?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúHey, are you doing okay today?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs something nice you can do for yourself this week?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhat are you going to do for you after this call?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhat do you like to do for fun?‚Äù ‚Üí Ask follow-up questions!
  • ‚ÄúHave you been able to get back to [insert hobby] lately?‚Äù
Offering Reassurance & Validation
  • ‚ÄúThat sounds really hard‚Äîthank you for sharing that with me.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI totally get why you‚Äôre feeling that way.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry that happened. Let‚Äôs see what we can do together.‚Äù
When discussing options (extensions or payment plans)
  • Start by checking in: ‚ÄúAre you doing okay today?‚Äù
  • Ask to do something nice (in the middle of the call)
  • Acknowledge stress or hardship before solutions
  • Offer reassurance: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to help, I promise it‚Äôs going to be ok.‚Äù
New loan or application
  • Take an interest while updating info or reviewing the app
  • Ask about hobbies‚Äîand follow up
  • Stay on the line through the full application
  • Treat it like building a relationship, not just a task
Follow-up or active account review
  • Warm greeting + genuine check-in
  • Ask if they‚Äôve had time for themselves‚Äîuse notes/hobbies
  • Connect early and stay present
  • If nothing personal is noted, ask‚Äîthen listen and respond
When a client is upset or we offer a refund
  • Pause and listen‚Äîlet them vent
  • ‚ÄúCan you help me understand what‚Äôs been going on?‚Äù
  • Say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry‚Äù before solutions
  • Avoid combatting emotion with logic
  • If solution isn‚Äôt enough, loop in a TL before ending
  • Stay calm, warm, and non-defensive

Note: If legal jargon or third parties are mentioned, stop and transfer‚Äîanother department will handle it.

Talking to someone who is past due
  • Open with ‚ÄúAre you okay?‚Äù‚Äîon PD1, don‚Äôt start with the payment.
  • If they‚Äôre worried, reassure:
    • No reattempt until next due date
    • No late fees or NSF charges
    • Standing with us won‚Äôt be affected
  • Validate the stress

Every call is a chance to build trust and restore hope.

COMPLIANCE MUST-HAVES

We‚Äôre not just here to help‚Äîwe‚Äôre here to protect.

  • SSN
  • Correct authorization type (TEL, WEB)
  • Read auth scripts correctly
  • Send the Future Payments email

AUTHORIZATION SCRIPTS & TYPES
pages.content:
AUTHORIZATION SCRIPTS

Read verbatim. Send the correct follow-up email. Stay compliant.

üí°

Authorization scripts

These authorization scripts came directly from an attorney. It is critical to read them exactly as they are written so that we are in complete compliance with federal law and regulations. These are to be used any time a client makes a change that would alter their original agreement.

  • Scripts must be read exactly as they are written
  • Future Payments/Extension email must be sent

EXTENSIONS, GRACE PERIOD, & PAUSE

AUTH SCRIPT

This script is used when a client uses a courtesy extension, emergency extension, or grace period, or if a client pauses their payments.

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will be moving your original payment due on [original due date] in the amount of [amount] to [new due date] in the amount of [amount]. This transaction will come out of your account ending in [last 4 digits of account or card number]. Your new pay in full date will now be [end date]. Is that correct? Do we have your permission to proceed?

Send the Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, PP email

GOOD FAITH PAYMENT

AUTH SCRIPT

This script is used when a client is going to make a $25 good faith payment.

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will be debiting a total of $25 on [due date] and moving your original payment of [amount] to [new due date]. This transaction will come out of your account ending in [last 4 digits of account or card number]. As a result, your new pay in full date will be [end date]. Is that correct and do I have your permission to proceed?

Send the Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, PP email

REFUND

AUTH SCRIPT ‚Äî Full Payment (or Full + Overdraft)

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will be refunding [amount] to the bank account ending in [last 4 of account number], and that will be deposited on [date of deposit]. Your next due date will be on [date] in the amount of [amount], using the same bank account ending in [last 4 of account number]. This will change your payoff date to [final pay date -- you will need to figure this out manually]. Do we have your permission to proceed?

AUTH SCRIPT ‚Äî Overdraft Fee Only

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will be refunding [amount] to the bank account ending in [last 4 of account number], and that will be deposited on [date of deposit]. Is that correct? Do we have your permission to proceed?

REFUND FOLLOW-UP (Underwriter)

Leave a follow-up for your underwriter to refund the payment, mark the payment refunded, and send the Future Payments email on your behalf.

Copy template for underwriter follow-up:

Full Payment Only:
Refund full payment + extra $15 [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.] and send the Future Payments email on RM's behalf.

Full Payment + Overdraft Fee:
Refund full payment + extra $15 [amount] and overdraft fee [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.] and send the Future Payments email on RM's behalf.

Overdraft Fee Only:
Refund overdraft fee + $15 [amount] into account ending in [last 4 of acct.] and send the Future Payments email on RM's behalf.

PAYMENT DOLLAR AMOUNT CHANGE

AUTH SCRIPT

This script is used when a payment dollar amount is adjusted, the client is making an early payment, or the client is going back to the minimum payments.

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will be debiting [amount] on [date] from [last 4 digits of bank account or card]. Your future due dates and payment amounts will be as follows: [read ALL payment amounts and dates]. All of these transactions will come out of the account(s)/card(s) previously mentioned. Your new pay in full date will be [end date]. Is that correct? Do we have your permission to proceed?

Send the Future Payments email

IMPORTANT NOTE: If this or any upcoming payment will not be processed through the payment method we have on file, you must confirm the details of each individual payment with the client (amount, date, and account/card) before ending the authorization script.

PAY FREQUENCY CHANGE

AUTH SCRIPT

This script is used any time a client updates their pay frequency while having an existing loan out.

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will be changing your pay frequency from [original pay frequency] to [new pay frequency], and changing your due date from [original due date] to [new due date], with a payment in the amount of [amount]. All future transactions will come out of your account ending in [last 4 digits of account or card number], with the new pay frequency set to [new pay frequency]. Your new pay in full date will be [end date]. Is that correct? Do we have your permission to proceed?

Send the Future Payments email

PAYMENT METHOD CHANGE

AUTH SCRIPT

This script is used any time a client updates their banking info (account OR card) while having an existing loan out. Please note: If a client changes their BANK ACCOUNT number and we've never taken payments from that account before, verify that the client's name is on the account BEFORE saving it inside of LMS.

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will be changing your bank account from [last 4 digits of original card/acct. #] to [last 4 digits of new card/acct. #]. All future transactions will come out of your account ending in [last 4 digits of new card/acct. #]. Is that correct? Do we have your permission to proceed?

Send the Future Payments email

PAYMENT PLAN

AUTH SCRIPT

This script is used when a client is put on a payment plan, makes changes to an existing payment plan (i.e., lowering/increasing payments), or resumes payment plan payments.

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will be debiting [amount] for the next [number of payments] payments (e.g., 6 payments of $65). The first payment will be pulled on [due date]. These transactions will come out of your account ending in [last 4 digits of account or card number]. Your pay in full date will now be [end date]. Is that correct? Do we have your permission to proceed?

Send the Courtesy, Emergency, GFP, PP email

PAST DUE

AUTH SCRIPT

This script is used when a client has had 2 or more returns in a row and wants to start making MINIMUM PAYMENTS again.

Hey [client name],

Before we get started, I want to make sure you understand that this call is being recorded for monitoring and quality control purposes. Is that okay? To confirm, we will resume payments on your account beginning [date] in the amount of [amount]. Your remaining due dates and payment amounts will be as follows: [read dates and amounts of ALL payments]. The transactions will come out of your bank account ending in [last 4 digits of bank account number]. Your new pay in full date will be [end date]. Is that correct? Do we have your permission to proceed?

Send the Future Payments email

AUTH TYPES

Correctly labeling payments is crucial for compliance. Here's the information you need to select the right type:

TEL

Any time you read a verbal authorization script, label it TEL. For more information about when an authorization script is required see more details here.

WEB

Any time a client schedules a payment online, the system will mark it as WEB. The only time you will mark the payment as WEB is if you spoke with the client over email (only applicable when scheduling a grace period or payoff).

PPD

Any time we are crediting (i.e., refunding) an account.

üß†

Important Notes

  • If you are rescheduling a payment on a past due client, look at what the authorization type was on the payment that returned and label it as such.
  • Do not change the authorization type to TEL if the client is just discussing the payment with you. The only time you change a payment to TEL is if an authorization script is read.

pages.content:
REQUIREMENTS

Compliance requirements and verification standards

SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBER

On every call (both inbound and outbound) you are required to verify the client's social before giving account info.

Verify SSN before sharing account information on every call.

NAME ON BANK ACCOUNT

When a client with an active loan updates their banking information, and the new account has never been used in any of our portfolios, you are required to verify that the account belongs to the client.

Verify through:

  • A voided check
  • A bank statement
  • A 3-way call with the bank

Verify:

  • The routing and account number
  • The client‚Äôs name on the account (no other details are needed)

This verification must be completed before saving the account as their primary payment method and before reading the authorization script.

Verification is not required if a client updates their payment method to a card.

ELECTRONIC SIGNATURE

The client must be the one to sign the loan agreement. The only exception is if another individual has Power of Attorney (POA). In that case, a copy of the POA must be uploaded to the client‚Äôs file before that person can complete the electronic signature.

AUTHORIZATION SCRIPTS

Authorization scripts are required anytime we make a change to a client who currently has an existing loan that alters what they originally agreed to in their loan documents. This includes:

  • Changing the payment method
  • Altering payment amounts (increasing or decreasing)
  • Adjusting payment dates
  • Changing the pay frequency
  • Refunding a payment
  • Resuming payments on a past-due account after two or more consecutive returns

AUTHORIZATION TYPES

It is critical for compliance that we label payments correctly. Each time we send a payment, we report to the bank how authorization was obtained for that payment.

  • The authorization type will always default to WEB when the client signs the loan agreement.
  • You must also select WEB if the client goes online to adjust a payment, update account details, etc.

To do this: go to Change Payments, select one payment, and update it to WEB (this will update all subsequent payments).

  • For all scenarios listed under Authorization Scripts, you must label all future payments as TEL.

Again, do this by going to Change Payments and adjusting one payment (which will update the rest).

EMAILS

There are specific scenarios where an email must be sent to clients:

Anytime an authorization script is read

Send the appropriate email: Future Payments, or CE / EE / GFP / PP (depending on the situation).

When denying a loan

Your underwriter will send this email for you.

When an application is pending due to missing details

It is critical to send the correct email template:

  • Missing Bank V/Esig ‚Üí both verification and signatures are missing
  • Missing Bank V ‚Üí bank verification is missing
  • Missing Esig ‚Üí loan document signatures are missing

CALLS, EMAILS & SCENARIOS

High-connection etiquette, clear emails, correct info, and what to do in special cases.

CALL ETIQUETTE

LINE DISCONNECTS

If a client calls and the line disconnects, you're required to call the client back ‚Äî regardless of whether they belong to you.

LOAN ASSIGNMENTS

New loans will be assigned to the last person who called the client and documented the script used in the notes ‚Äî unless the client specifically asks for someone else.

UNCOMFORTABLE PHONE CALLS

If a conversation becomes inappropriate or uncomfortable, politely end the call and inform your TL afterward for guidance.

EMAILS

CLIENT EMAILS

Whenever a client emails with inquiries regarding extensions, loan setup, balance inquiries, etc., it's now mandatory to call them. If they don't answer, also send an email (preferably using a template). If no template fits, use the phrases below.

EMAIL RESPONSES

Validate first‚Äîemail can flatten emotion. Use the Sample Email Response or Need Verbal Authorization templates when possible. If not, try language like:

I'm so sorry for the miscommunication. I can absolutely understand why this would be so confusing and I want you to know it was never my intention to mislead you. I always want my clients to be informed and clearly understand how this works.

I want to make sure I get this resolved right away. When would be a good time for me to call you?

I promise that by the end of the call you will feel taken care of. I will get this cleaned up so that it doesn't cause you any more stress!

CONTACT INFO

ADDRESS

If a client or business requests our address, provide the tribe's address: 600 F Street, Ste. 3, #721, Arcata, CA 95521.

  • Avoid mentioning iLS ‚Äî it's irrelevant to our clients.
  • Do not share upper management info; provide your Team Lead‚Äôs email if they want to contact higher-ups.
FAX NUMBER

If a client wishes to fax loan documents, notify your TL for assistance. Provide the fax number (800) 784-6798 and instruct them to sign pages 2, 3, 12, and 14, check the box on page 11, and fax the complete agreement (14 pages) back to us.

PHONE NUMBERS
  • CCL: (800) 238-0941
  • PCL: (800) 236-0809
  • TFG: (800) 548-9571

SPECIFIC SCENARIOS

UNLINKED NUMBER

If a client calls from a phone number not linked to their account, ask if they want it saved as their primary.

  • YES: Update and save as primary.
  • NO: Leave a follow-up for your TL to add it as a non-primary number.
SPANISH SPEAKING

If a Spanish-speaking client calls and you don't speak Spanish, leave a follow-up for your TL to have a Spanish-speaking RM call them back (don‚Äôt hunt one down mid-call).

SAFETY CONCERN

If a client expresses suicidal thoughts, direct them to the suicide hotline at (800) 273-8255.

CALLER ON BEHALF OF

If someone calls in on a client's behalf, check if we have authorization.

  • YES: Proceed as usual; verify last 4 of the client‚Äôs SSN.

TRANSFERRING CALLS

Whenever a client calls in, transfer them directly to their assigned Relationship Manager (RM). The RM‚Äôs role is to create opportunities to connect with clients; more frequent interactions strengthen trust and reduce repeat explanations.

The goal is simple: let Relationship Managers handle their own clients as much as possible. Clients prefer one reliable point of contact.

Important Notes

DISPOSITIONING & PHONE STATUS

Select the right codes and mark numbers correctly‚Äîconsistently.

DISPOSITIONING CALLS

Select the correct disposition code consistently to identify successful patterns and trends for training purposes. Below are the codes and when to use them.

  • DASHBO - Dashboard Task: Anytime you manually dial a client from a task on your dashboard.
  • INBOUN - Inbound Call: Anytime you take an inbound call.
  • LISTAN - List Answer: When you dial from the LIST and the client answers.
  • LISTVM - List VM: When you dial from the LIST and leave a voicemail.
  • OTHER- Other: Any other scenario that doesn't fit the above situations use this.

WHEN TO MARK A PHONE NUMBER BAD

Mark a phone number as bad if:

  • When you get a green screen error.
  • When you get a dial timed out notification.
PLEASE NOTE: In the two scenarios listed above, if the client has ever had a loan with us do NOT mark these numbers bad. This is ONLY for new clients.
  • Dialing to a fax number.
  • Dialing to a disconnected number.
  • Someone answers, confirming it's the wrong number.
  • A call back confirms the wrong number.
  • Dialing a business number, and the client doesn't work there.
  • Dialing a business number, and an automated system connects; hang up immediately and mark it as bad.

WHEN TO MARK A PHONE NUMBER DO NOT CALL

Please note: If the client has multiple phone numbers on file, ensure ALL are marked DNC.

Mark a phone DNC when:

  • A client requests to be removed from the list.
  • A client requests not to be called or contacted. (If the client requests not to be contacted, be sure to mark their email(s) DNE as well.)

OTHER SCENARIOS

  • If the line doesn't ring or connect to a voicemail within 2 minutes, disconnect.
  • If the line is ringing and doesn't connect to voicemail or error out within 2 minutes, disconnect.

All workflows and scripts organized into expandable sections.

Customer Edited Payment

Steps / Process

This change can only be made if the client does NOT have an existing loan (unless it's a card see that section for more details). Follow the questions below to determine what to do:

    • IF NO: Mark the follow-up complete.
    • IF YES: Did the client sign the loan agreement already?

For PCL & TFG

In this case, ensure you save the original payment method as primary and send the Future Payments email with the original payment method.
  • YOU REACH THE CLIENT: If you were able to reach the client and the $1 fee was successfully processed:
    • Check the payment table to ensure that the new card is scheduled as the payment method for the next payment.

Customer Unselects Pay by Card

Steps / Process

At any time, the client can unselect a card as their default payment method. In the event you receive a follow-up that says "Customer Edited Information: Pay by Credit Card" please follow the steps below:

  • Check Loan Agreement: Verify if the bank account that is now saved as the primary account is listed in the loan documents.
  • IF NO:

  • IF YES:
    • Check the payment table to ensure the pending payment is set up with the bank account that is now saved as the primary account.

    • Go to Change Payments and ensure all future payments are labeled as WEB.
    • Call the client to inform them that you noticed the change they made online and as a result, our system will now default payments through their bank account.
    • Send the Future Payments email.

  • If you receive a follow-up warning that a client has two loans out, please follow the process outlined in the PD Process under the "Payment Fail Follow-ups".

Steps / Process
  • If you receive a follow-up indicating the client updated their military status, go to Edit Customer and check that Military is not set to ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù
  • If it is, please see your Team Lead for further guidance.

Reminder of Next Due Date

  • If you receive a follow-up that says RNDDET or RNDD follow these steps:
  • Call the client (unless it specifically says to only email)
  • Email the client using the template titled Reminder Of Next Due Date

Valued Client (VC) Process

Guidance and call scripts for Valued Clients (paid-in-full).

VC PROCESS

Valued clients with paid-in-full accounts must be called every 6 weeks. Move actions that fall on holidays to the previous business day. If a client took a loan with another portfolio, follow the LWOP process (no MP).

Rotation:

  • CCL scripts 10‚Äì13
  • PCL scripts 2‚Äì5
  • TFG scripts 6‚Äì9

Important: Check for past-due balances on older loans before the VC process; waive if possible. If not, proceed with VC. For clients with past-due loans wanting a new one, they must pay the old loan‚Äôs principal first.

PROMOTIONS

Promos are offered during the VC process and occasionally by management. Retention comes from excellent service‚Äîfocus on meaningful connection over funds.

If a client asks for a promo:

  • Offer only if the last POC included one OR if offered within the last 2 weeks.
  • Referral taken? The referrer can get an extension on their next loan (code: VC Referral).

Notes:

  • Do not match other portfolios‚Äô promos.
  • Online applications: if they haven‚Äôt signed, you may apply a promo automatically (if eligible).
TYVC PROCESS
  • Old PD Loan: Ask TL if PD can be waived; if not, proceed with VC. For a new loan, client must pay PD principal first.
  • PIF on a Card: Consider lowering limit (payment plan/OPS/DC), set next action to 6 weeks, send Thank You VC email.
  • PDBW/Test-PDBW: Leave TL a 5-business-day follow-up to confirm payoff so list can move to VCs.
  • Referrals: If PIF on first due date and status is Final Payment Processed, wait for settlement before approving new loan.
